On this page

Authority Kernel ​

The Security Layer Powering Authority Nanos

Overview ​

The Authority Kernel (AK) is the security subsystem that makes Authority Nanos the premier unikernel for AI agents. It implements a capability-based security model with comprehensive audit logging, ensuring that autonomous agents operate within strictly defined boundaries while maintaining complete auditability.

Authority Nanos = Nanos unikernel + Authority Kernel subsystem

Security Invariants ​

The Authority Kernel enforces four fundamental security invariants:

INV-1: No-Bypass Invariant ​

Every external effect occurs through a kernel-mediated syscall.

The unikernel boundary ensures no direct hardware or network access bypasses the kernel.

INV-2: Capability Invariant ​

Every effectful syscall must carry a valid, non-revoked capability whose scope subsumes the request.

c
s64 ak_capability_validate(
    ak_capability_t *cap,
    ak_cap_type_t required_type,
    const char *resource,
    const char *method,
    u8 *run_id
);
1
2
3
4
5
6
7

INV-3: Budget Invariant ​

The sum of in-flight and committed costs never exceeds budget.

Admission control prevents resource exhaustion:

c
s64 ak_budget_reserve(ak_budget_tracker_t *tracker,
                      ak_resource_type_t type, u64 amount);
1
2

INV-4: Log Commitment Invariant ​

Each committed transition appends a log entry whose hash chain validates from genesis to head.

Tamper-evident audit log with hash chain:

c
s64 ak_audit_append(u8 *pid, u8 *run_id, u16 op,
                    u8 *req_hash, u8 *res_hash, u8 *policy_hash);
1
2

Architecture ​

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                      Agent Process                          │
│  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐   │
│  │                   Agent Code                         │   │
│  │  • LLM Inference       • Tool Execution             │   │
│  │  • State Management    • Communication              │   │
│  └────────────────────────┬────────────────────────────┘   │
│                           │ AK Syscalls (1024-1100)        │
├───────────────────────────┼─────────────────────────────────┤
│                           ▼                                 │
│  ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐   │
│  │              Authority Kernel                        │   │
│  │  ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐            │   │
│  │  │Capability│ │  Audit   │ │  Policy  │            │   │
│  │  │  System  │ │   Log    │ │  Engine  │            │   │
│  │  └──────────┘ └──────────┘ └──────────┘            │   │
│  │  ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐ ┌──────────┐            │   │
│  │  │  Typed   │ │   IPC    │ │ Syscall  │            │   │
│  │  │   Heap   │ │Transport │ │ Dispatch │            │   │
│  │  └──────────┘ └──────────┘ └──────────┘            │   │
│  └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘   │
│                    Nanos Kernel                             │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

Syscall Interface ​

NumberNameDescription
1024READRead object from typed heap
1025ALLOCAllocate new heap object
1026WRITEUpdate object with JSON Patch
1027DELETESoft-delete object
1028QUERYQuery objects by predicate
1029BATCHAtomic batch operations
1030COMMITCheckpoint audit log
1031CALLInvoke tool in WASM sandbox
1032SPAWNCreate child agent
1033SENDSend message to agent
1034RECVReceive messages
1035RESPONDSend response to orchestrator
1036ASSERTRecord assertion
1037INFERENCEInvoke LLM

Components ​

Capability System (ak_capability.h/c) ​

  • HMAC-SHA256 signed tokens
  • Scope-based access control
  • Key rotation with grace period
  • Constant-time verification
  • Immediate revocation

Typed Heap (ak_heap.h/c) ​

  • Versioned objects with CAS semantics
  • JSON Schema validation
  • RFC 6902 JSON Patch support
  • Transaction support for BATCH
  • Taint tracking

Audit Log (ak_audit.h/c) ​

  • Hash-chained entries
  • Crash recovery
  • External anchoring
  • Replay bundle support

Policy Engine (ak_policy.h/c) ​

  • JSON/YAML policy format
  • Budget enforcement
  • Tool allowlists
  • Domain restrictions
  • Taint flow rules

IPC Transport (ak_ipc.h/c) ​

  • Framed protocol with CRC-32C
  • Sequence-based replay protection
  • JSON serialization

Syscall Dispatcher (ak_syscall.h/c) ​

  • Central enforcement point
  • 10-stage validation pipeline
  • Per-operation handlers

Configuration ​

Policy Format (JSON) ​

json
{
  "version": "1.0",
  "budgets": {
    "tokens": 100000,
    "calls": 50,
    "inference_ms": 60000,
    "file_bytes": 10485760
  },
  "tools": {
    "allow": ["file_read", "http_get"],
    "deny": ["shell_exec"]
  },
  "domains": {
    "allow": ["*.github.com"],
    "deny": ["*.internal"]
  }
}

Security Considerations ​

Fail-Closed Design ​

All validation functions return denial by default:

  • Unknown capability → denied
  • Missing policy → denied
  • Taint violation → denied

Timing Attack Resistance ​

Capability verification uses constant-time comparison:

c
static boolean constant_time_compare(u8 *a, u8 *b, u64 len)
{
    u8 result = 0;
    for (u64 i = 0; i < len; i++)
        result |= a[i] ^ b[i];
    return result == 0;
}
1
2
3
4
5
6
7

Capability Revocation ​

Revocation is immediate and persistent:

  • Stored in revocation map
  • Survives kernel restart
  • Logged to audit trail

Audit Log Integrity ​

Hash chain prevents undetected tampering:

hash[n] = SHA256(hash[n-1] || entry[n])
1

Python Integration ​

Authority Nanos provides comprehensive Python support through the authority_nanos SDK, enabling developers to build production-grade AI agents in Python.

Python Agent Architecture ​

┌─────────────────────────────────┐
│     Python Agent Code           │
│  (anthropic, openai, langchain) │
└────────────┬────────────────────┘
             │
             ▼ (syscalls 1024-1037)
┌─────────────────────────────────┐
│  Authority Python SDK           │
│  (authority_nanos module)       │
│  - Typed heap (alloc/read/write)│
│  - LLM inference                │
│  - Policy enforcement           │
│  - Audit logging                │
└────────────┬────────────────────┘
             │
             ▼ (ctypes FFI)
┌─────────────────────────────────┐
│    Authority Kernel (libak)     │
│    - Capability validation      │
│    - Policy evaluation          │
│    - Budget enforcement         │
│    - Audit log commitment       │
└────────────┬────────────────────┘
             │
             ▼ (syscalls)
┌─────────────────────────────────┐
│       Nanos Kernel              │
│  - Memory management            │
│  - I/O dispatch                 │
│  - Network handling             │
└─────────────────────────────────┘

Python Syscall Routing ​

Python agents use syscalls 1024-1037 to communicate with the Authority Kernel:

python
# Python Agent
from authority_nanos import AuthorityKernel

with AuthorityKernel() as ak:
    # This Python call becomes a syscall
    handle = ak.alloc("counter", b'{"value": 0}')
1
2
3
4
5
6

Syscall flow:

  1. Python SDK method called (e.g., alloc())
  2. SDK marshals arguments to ctypes structures
  3. syscall() instruction triggered with AK_SYS_ALLOC (1025)
  4. Authority Kernel validates:
    • Capability: Does agent have permission?
    • Policy: Does policy allow this operation?
    • Budget: Is budget available?
    • Type: Is argument valid?
  5. Kernel executes or denies
  6. Result returned to Python
  7. SDK unmarshals result
  8. Python receives exception or value

Security Model for Python ​

All four security invariants are enforced at the syscall boundary:

INV-1: No-Bypass Invariant

  • All Python I/O must go through SDK methods
  • No direct hardware access possible in unikernel
  • File operations, network, and LLM calls all syscall through kernel

INV-2: Capability Invariant

  • Each syscall carries a capability token
  • SDK embeds token in syscall arguments
  • Kernel validates HMAC-SHA256 token before allowing operation
  • Example: Only agents with network capability can call http_get()

INV-3: Budget Invariant

  • Budgets enforced per-syscall
  • Python SDK checks budget before issuing syscall
  • Kernel also enforces as safety check
  • BudgetExceededError raised when exceeded

INV-4: Log Commitment Invariant

  • Every syscall appends to hash-chained audit log
  • Python can retrieve via get_audit_log()
  • Log includes: operation, arguments, result, timestamp, hash chain

Performance Considerations ​

Syscall Overhead ​

Each Python SDK operation triggers a syscall. Typical costs:

OperationCost
alloc()1 syscall + memory allocation
read()1 syscall
write()1 syscall + policy check
infer()1-N syscalls (includes LLM network I/O)
http_get()1 syscall + network round-trip

Optimization Tips ​

  1. Batch operations - Use batch syscall for multiple updates
  2. Cache results - Store LLM responses in typed heap
  3. Minimize network - Batch HTTP requests
  4. Stream responses - Use infer_streaming() for large responses

Python + WASM Integration ​

Python agents can call WASM tools via the kernel:

python
# Python agent calls WASM tool
result = ak.call_tool("crypto_sign", {
    "data": message.encode(),
    "key": signing_key
})
1
2
3
4
5

Flow:

  1. Python calls call_tool()
  2. SDK marshals arguments, issues AK_SYS_CALL syscall
  3. Kernel validates capability and policy
  4. Kernel routes to WASM sandbox
  5. WASM module executes with hostcalls capability-gated
  6. Result returned through kernel
  7. Python receives result

Thread Safety & Concurrency ​

The Python SDK is not thread-safe at the syscall level. Options:

  1. Sequential execution - Use single-threaded agents
  2. Per-thread instances - Each thread has own AuthorityKernel()
  3. Async/await - Use Python asyncio within single thread

Example:

python
import asyncio
from authority_nanos import AuthorityKernel

async def agent_task(task_id):
    # Each task gets own kernel instance
    with AuthorityKernel() as ak:
        # Sequential operations within this kernel
        result = await ak.infer_async("gpt-4", messages)
        return result

# Run multiple tasks concurrently
results = asyncio.run(
    asyncio.gather(*[agent_task(i) for i in range(4)])
)
1
2
3
4
5
6

Policy Enforcement for Python ​

Python agents respect the same policy format as C agents:

json
{
  "fs": {
    "read": ["/usr/lib/python3.11/**", "/app/**"],
    "write": ["/tmp/**"]
  },
  "net": {
    "dns": ["api.anthropic.com"],
    "connect": ["dns:api.anthropic.com:443"]
  },
  "infer": {
    "models": ["claude-*"],
    "max_tokens": 200000
  },
  "budgets": {
    "tokens": 200000,
    "wall_time_ms": 600000
  }
}
1

16
17
18

When Python agent attempts denied operation:

python
# Policy does not allow file write to /etc/shadow
try:
    ak.file_write("/etc/shadow", data)
except OperationDeniedError as e:
    print(f"Policy denied: {e}")
    # Log shows: FS_WRITE /etc/shadow denied by policy
1
2
3
4
5
6

Python SDK Internals ​

The SDK provides two layers:

Layer 1: Low-level ctypes bindings (internal)

  • Direct syscall invocation
  • Memory marshalling
  • Error code conversion

Layer 2: High-level Python API (public)

  • Pythonic error handling
  • Type safety
  • Context managers
  • Streaming support
python
# High-level API (recommended)
with AuthorityKernel() as ak:
    data = ak.read(handle)

# Low-level API (internal)
from authority_nanos.core import LibakLoader
libak = LibakLoader.load()
libak.ak_syscall(Syscall.READ, ...)
1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8

LLM Integration Specifics ​

Python's LLM support includes both direct kernel calls and standard SDK integration:

Direct kernel inference:

python
response = ak.infer("claude-3-sonnet-20240229",
    messages=[{"role": "user", "content": "Hi"}],
    max_tokens=1000)
1
2
3

Through SDK client (anthropic, openai):

python
import anthropic
client = anthropic.Anthropic(api_key=key)
response = client.messages.create(
    model="claude-3-sonnet-20240229",
    messages=[...]
)
# Under the hood: uses Python SDK internally if available
1
2
3
4
5
6
7

Error Handling Strategy ​

Python agent error handling pattern:

python
from authority_nanos import (
    AuthorityKernelError,
    OperationDeniedError,
    BudgetExceededError,
    CapabilityError
)

try:
    result = ak.infer("gpt-4", messages)
except OperationDeniedError:
    # Policy denied operation
    print("Policy denied")
except BudgetExceededError:
    # Budget exhausted
    print("Budget exceeded")
except CapabilityError:
    # Invalid capability
    print("Capability error")
except AuthorityKernelError as e:
    # General Authority error
    print(f"Authority error: {e.code}")
1

  • Error code
  • Human-readable message
  • Denial/capability details for debugging
